channel.title: Geom lol
channel.description:
Not really homework, but help would be appreciated.
Heres my problem: I have a circle drawn onto a cartesian plane. The center of this circle is at the origin (0, 0). I know the radius of this circle (26)
How can I determine the coordinates of a point on the perimeter of the circle, given a bearing (angle from North clockwise)?
Edit: I think I can do it now. Geometric verctors sound right? Polar -> Cartesian should do it.

item.title: Geom lol
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

Yeah, got that. Thanks.

@HexKey: You cant use a bearing, you gotta convert it into a proper trig angle first.

Read full topic

item.title: Geom lol
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

To convert polar coordinates (r, theta) to Cartesian coordinates (x, y):

x = r * cos(theta)
y = r * sin(theta)

Read full topic

item.title: Geom lol
item.dc:creator: @Hex_Key Hex Key
item.description:
@Hex_Key wrote:

This is basic SOH/CAH/TOA

you know the angle (bearin) you know the hypotonuse. plug it in the equation.

Read full topic
